Project.Abstract: Unraveling the mechanisms by which (+) strand RNA viruses initiate replication is of eminent importance for a better understanding of viral reproduction, accumulation and virus-induced pathogenesis. Identification of the mechanisms that underlie these strategies will reveal new, fundamental features of basic RNA structures and their biological function. The objectives of this proposal are to unravel the structural and functional properties of two classes of RNA cis-acting control elements of replication of polio and Coxsackie viruses, the oriR (origin of replication) and a recently discovered control element dubbed CRE (cis-acting replication element). The oriR is a 11pnt entity, present at the 3'-end of the (+) strand that functions as a complex tertiary structural element. CRE is a ~55pnt hairpin of which the loop is known to serve as a primer for uridylylation of the peptide VPg, which acts as a primer for (-) strand synthesis. The three-dimensional structures and exact nature by which oriR and CRE recognize their partners and how they operate in RNA genome replication remains, however, entirely unknown. This proposal aims at solving these important questions by using a combination of biophysical, biochemical and virological approaches. The long-term goal of these studies is to unravel the molecular and structural determinants of regulation by these elements at the atomic level using the complementary expertise of a structural biology/biophysical group and a molecular biology/virology group. The short-time goal, presented in this proposal, is to determine the high-resolution NMR structures and dynamics of oriR and the CREs of Coxsackie and poliovirus. The size of the oriR is too large to be handled by standard heteronuclear NMR methodology. Thus, newly developed NMR methodology, involving (partially) reiterated RNA samples and macroscopic alignment will be applied to tackle this large system by NMR. The CREs will be studied by NMR in the free and bound state to the small uridylylated peptide VPg-pUpU. This will reveal possible conformational changes and dynamics, important for function. Also, a structural comparison of the CREs from two sources with different sequences will reveal important common structural motifs. The solved structures will serve as a rationale for functional analysis, by looking at phenotypic behavior of, for instance, selected mutants. Thus, site-directed mutagenesis will be used to modify the control elements, and the resulting effect of structural changes in biological properties of the mutant genomes will be investigated. The outcome of these studies will enrich the understanding of RNA folding and identify specific loci, either at the protein or RNA level, involved in viral replication.
